title: 112_hr3314
content: The Act may be cited as the "Climate Change Health Protection and Promotion Act". Congress acknowledges the impact of climate change on public health. The "Climate Change Health Protection and Promotion Act" emphasizes the need for the Federal Government to work with various entities to prepare health systems for the impacts of climate change and ensure health professionals are equipped to address these challenges. The "Climate Change Health Protection and Promotion Act" focuses on addressing the health impacts of climate change, preparing for these impacts, identifying vulnerable communities, improving health equity, and integrating health policy into climate change responses. It also aims to promote research, interdisciplinary partnerships, and collaboration among stakeholders. The "Climate Change Health Protection and Promotion Act" aims to enhance preparedness activities, public health infrastructure, and encourage awareness of climate change impacts on health. It also seeks to assist developing nations in preparing health systems for climate change impacts through research, partnerships, and collaboration among stakeholders. SEC. 3. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER LAWS. This Act does not limit the authority of any Federal department or agency under any other law and does not authorize any violation of any law. SEC. 4. NATIONAL STRATEGIC ACTION PLAN. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must publish a strategic action plan within 2 years to help health professionals prepare for and respond to the impacts of climate change on public health, consulting with relevant agencies. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will publish a strategic action plan within 2 years to assist health professionals in preparing for and responding to the health effects of climate change. This plan will involve collaboration with various stakeholders and provide opportunities for public input. The plan will focus on developing and improving disease surveillance systems to monitor and respond to health-related impacts of climate change. The curr_chunk discusses health-related effects of climate change, including water, food, vector-borne diseases, pulmonary and cardiovascular effects, air pollution, hazardous algal blooms, mental health impacts, and the health of vulnerable communities. The curr_chunk focuses on creating tools for predicting and monitoring public health effects of climate change at various levels, developing public health communications strategies for extreme weather events, and implementing local and community-based health interventions for climate-related health impacts. The curr_chunk discusses strategies for identifying and prioritizing vulnerable communities to climate change health effects, developing health communication programs for public education, and promoting preparedness and response strategies for climate change and public health. Developing academic and regional centers of excellence focused on researching relationships between climate change and health, expanding the public health workforce's capacity to respond to climate change effects, supporting academic fellowships on climate change health effects, and training health ministry officials from developing nations to strengthen their capacity. The curr_chunk discusses the capacity of nations to prepare for and respond to health effects of climate change, build an international network of public health professionals with climate change knowledge, assess climate change public health strategies, and support the development of such strategies at various levels. The curr_chunk focuses on the implementation and support of preparedness, communication, and response plans at various levels to address health threats of climate change. It also mentions creating a program to advance research on the effects of climate change on public health across Federal agencies. The curr_chunk focuses on research, prioritizing infrastructure projects, and coordinating preparedness for climate change health impacts. It also includes providing technical assistance for the development and implementation of preparedness and response plans to reduce health threats of climate change. The Secretary shall revise the national strategic action plan every 4 years to reflect new information on critical environmental health parameters, the impacts of climate change on public health, and strategies for responding to these impacts. The Secretary will implement the national strategic action plan through various public health programs and initiatives, including research conducted by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to assist health professionals in preparing for and responding to health threats. The national strategic action plan will fund research and preparedness planning at various levels to address the health effects of climate change. Other activities determined appropriate by the Director will also be carried out to respond to these impacts on public health. The Secretary will establish a science advisory board with 10-20 members appointed based on expertise in public health, climate change, and other relevant disciplines. The board will provide advice on the impacts of climate change on public health and strategies to prepare and respond to these impacts. The science advisory board will advise the Secretary on the impacts of climate change on public health and provide the best available science for the national strategic action plan. The science advisory board will advise the Secretary on the impacts of climate change on public health and provide the best available science for the national strategic action plan. SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary aims to collaborate with the National Research Council and the Institute of Medicine to assess health professionals' needs in preparing for climate change impacts on public health and recommend programs to address those needs. The report must be submitted to Congress and the Secretary within a year of the agreement. Additionally, the Secretary will offer to collaborate on Climate Change Health Protection and Promotion Reports. The Secretary will collaborate with the National Research Council and the Institute of Medicine to prepare periodic reports on the health impacts of climate change, reviewing scientific developments and recommending changes to the national strategic action plan. Reports must be submitted to Congress and the Secretary every 4 years starting in 2015. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "health impact assessment" as a method to evaluate the effects of policies on population health and "national strategic action plan" as a plan issued under section 4. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Funds necessary for this Act will be appropriated to the Secretary of HHS and may be distributed to various entities. The funds should supplement existing public health funding, not replace it.
